title: Your product is a theme park
text:
Your product is a theme park

A practical way to evaluate what to fixÂ next.

Disclaimer: Some visuals in this article are AI-generated. Iâ€™m using them only to help explain the ideas more clearly. These visuals are not intended for commercial use, and Iâ€™m not monetizing this article. If any visual resembles an existing work, itâ€™s unintentionalÂ , please reach out and I will credit or removeÂ it.

Itâ€™s Saturday afternoon.

The park is packed, but something feelsâ€¦Â off.

The entrance queue is long and chaotic. Some visitors argue with staff because they â€œalready bought tickets,â€ but the scan keeps failing. A few families give up and leave before they even stepÂ inside.

Inside the park, the crowd gathers in one area, one â€œrideâ€ that everyone seems to know. Meanwhile, several other attractions sit quiet, almost empty. Not because theyâ€™re bad, but because visitors canâ€™t find them. The signage is confusing, the map is overwhelming, and the routes donâ€™t feel intuitive.

At the souvenir shop, sales are down. The operators swear the merchandise is fine. The finance team wonders if prices are wrong. The product team thinks maybe the park needs â€œa newÂ ride.â€

And then the feedback boothÂ opens:

  • â€œItâ€™s too hard to getÂ in.â€
  • â€œI didnâ€™t know where toÂ go.â€
  • â€œI got tired quickly.â€
  • â€œIt wasnâ€™t worth itÂ today.â€

Hereâ€™s the uncomfortable truth: the park isnâ€™t failing because it lacks rides. Itâ€™s failing because the team doesnâ€™t share a reliable way to evaluate what to fixÂ next.

Thatâ€™s why I love this metaphor: Your product is a theme park. And evaluation is renovation planning.

Not â€œshipping more features.â€

Not â€œadding more content.â€

Not â€œguessing based on the loudest voice in theÂ room.â€

Renovation planning.

The mapping: if the metaphor is true, what isÂ what?

Once you accept the â€œtheme parkâ€ frame, you stop seeing your product as a list of features, and start seeing it as a place peopleÂ visit.

Hereâ€™s the simplestÂ mapping:

  • Visitor = your user / audience
    They come with expectations, emotions, and limitedÂ time.
  • Access = your entry points
    Landing pages, SEO/social entry, app open, onboarding, login, paywall moments, notificationsâ€Šâ€”â€Ševerything that determines whether they can enter smoothly.
  • Zones/Platforms = contexts
    Home, feed, article page, video page, search, profile, commerce, chatâ€Šâ€”â€Šeach is a â€œzoneâ€ with aÂ promise.
  • Rides/Attractions = features
    Recommendation modules, player, comment, follow, save, share, checkout, personalization, bundlesâ€Šâ€”â€Šanything interactive that createsÂ value.
  • Ticketing + footfall = growth and retention signals
    Traffic, activation, frequency, DAU/WAU, returning visits.
  • Satisfaction kiosks = experience signals
    NPS/CSAT, complaint themes, qualitative feedback, sentiment.
  • Souvenir shops = monetization
    Ads yield, conversion, subscription, affiliate, revenue perÂ session.

The point is to make evaluation shared. Because every team already understands parks: people arrive, walk around, try things, leave, then decide whether to comeÂ back.

Renovation is bigger than â€œbuild newÂ ridesâ€

Most teams default to the same move: build something new. In theme park terms, thatâ€™s like responding to complaints by saying, â€œLetâ€™s add a roller coaster.â€ Sometimes, yes. But often the bigger wins come from renovations you donâ€™t celebrate in a launchÂ post.

Renovation canÂ mean:

  • Refurbish: improve UX, speed, reliability, visualÂ clarity
  • Move: change information architecture, reposition modules, rerouteÂ journeys
  • Disable: remove clutter, reduce cognitive load, kill distractions
  • Build new: new capabilities or new â€œridesâ€ when you have clear unmetÂ needs
  • Expand: new zones/platforms/channels
  • Improve accessibility: low-end devices, localization, inclusion, betterÂ defaults

A strong evaluation doesnâ€™t just say â€œwhat to build.â€ It tells you what renovation pays back fastest, with leastÂ risk.

Why renovate: experience, growth,Â revenue

In parks, you can renovate for different reasons:

  • Experience: visitors feel satisfied and safe, not confused or exhausted
  • Growth: more people come, and they come moreÂ often
  • Revenue: more people buy, upgrade, or convert perÂ visit

In product, itâ€™s the same. A simple rule helps align everyone:

If a proposal canâ€™t clearly explain which outcome it moves (experience, growth, or revenue)â€Šâ€”â€Šand how weâ€™ll measure itâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s notÂ ready.

The evaluation method: Quant + Qual + Triangulation

This is where teams usually break. One side says: â€œShow me the data.â€ The other says: â€œBut users saidâ€¦â€. A theme park canâ€™t run on onlyÂ one.

When â€œdata says one thingâ€ and â€œusers sayÂ anotherâ€

Sometimes the dashboard and the interviews donâ€™t just add nuanceâ€Šâ€”â€Šthey contradict each other. And when that happens, teams either (1) pick the narrative they prefer, or (2) get stuck inÂ debate.

A stronger approach is to design evaluation so that discrepancies become useful follow-ups, not dead ends, by running simultaneous triangulation: point qualitative and quantitative methods at the same users, at the same time, around the same questions.

Quant = whatÂ happened

Tickets sold. Footfall. Queue times. Ride completion rates. Drop-offs. Revenue per visitor. In productÂ terms:

  • traffic, CTR, scroll depth, completion, retention, conversion
  • funnel drop-offs (entry â†’ explore â†’ consume â†’ return/pay)
  • latency, errors, crashes, performance

Quant is powerful because it scales, but it can also mislead when you donâ€™t knowÂ why.

Qual = why itÂ happened

Observation, interviews, feedback booths, frontline notes. In productÂ terms:

  • user interviews, usability tests, session recordings
  • open feedback, customer supportÂ tickets
  • editorial/CS/ops insights from the frontÂ line

Qual makes the invisible visible, but it can also exaggerate if you donâ€™t know how common itÂ is.

Triangulation = what weÂ trust

Triangulation is when you use quant + qual together to make â€œdecision-grade truth.â€ A practical way to rememberÂ it:

  • Quant without qual = confident but oftenÂ wrong
  • Qual without quant = convincing but notÂ scalable
  • Both together = alignedÂ action

A tiny checklist helps:

  • Do we see the same pattern in at least twoÂ sources?
  • Does it hold across segments (new vs loyal, channel,Â device)?
  • Can we locate it in a specific journeyÂ stage?

That last one matters a lot. Because evaluation isnâ€™t only about whatâ€™s broken. Itâ€™s about where itâ€™sÂ broken.

Two cycles: open up wide, then narrow downÂ twice

In renovation work, the mistake isnâ€™t â€œwe didnâ€™t try hard enough.â€ Itâ€™s usually â€œwe narrowed too early.â€ So I like to run evaluation in twoÂ cycles:

  • Cycle 1: Find the right problem
    Open up (collect signals broadly), then narrow down (pinpoint the real friction in the journey).
  • Cycle 2: Build the right fix
    Open up again (explore renovation options), then narrow down again (choose, test, and ship the bestÂ bet).

In park terms: the first cycle is understanding whatâ€™s actually ruining the day. The second cycle is renovating in a way that truly improves the day, without breaking the rest of the park. Design teams often describe this as a widely-used diverge/converge processÂ model.

The visitor journey: where evaluation reallyÂ starts

If your product is a park, then your evaluation should follow the visitorâ€™s day.

Not your org chart. Not your feature list. A simple five-stage journey is enough to organizeÂ truth:

  1. Pre-Visit
  2. Arrival
  3. Exploration
  4. Departure
  5. Post-Visit

And in every stage, we ask the same questions:

  • What does quantÂ show?
  • What does qualÂ reveal?
  • What do we trust after triangulation?
  • What renovation does itÂ imply?

Letâ€™s walk throughÂ it.

1) Pre-Visit: before they enter theÂ gate

This is where your users decide whether your park is even worth visiting.

Quant signals

  • acquisition mix (SEO, social, referral, direct)
  • CTR from entryÂ surfaces
  • bounce rate / immediate exits
  • first-time conversion rate

Qual signals

  • expectation mismatch (â€œI thought this would beÂ Xâ€¦â€)
  • unclear value proposition
  • credibility gaps (trust cuesÂ missing)
  • wrong promise from headlines/thumbnails

Typical parkÂ symptom

People saw the billboard, but didnâ€™t buy aÂ ticket.

Renovation implication

Donâ€™t touch rides yet. Fix the promise. Fix the sign. Fix the first impression.

2) Arrival: the entrance and the first 60Â seconds

Some products lose users not because the core value is weak, but because the gate isÂ painful.

Quant signals

  • load speed, crashÂ rate
  • onboarding completion
  • login friction andÂ drop-off
  • â€œtime to first meaningful actionâ€

Qual signals

  • â€œI donâ€™t know what to doÂ hereâ€
  • confusing navigation
  • paywall shock (â€œwhy am I blocked already?â€)
  • unclear nextÂ step

Typical parkÂ symptom

The gate is the problem, not theÂ rides.

Renovation implication

Reduce friction. Make the first step obvious. Remove unnecessary checkpoints.

3) Exploration: when they roam and choose attractions

This is where your product either feels aliveâ€¦ or exhausting.

Quant signals

  • module CTR (recommendations, related content, navigation blocks)
  • scroll depth, continuation rate
  • search successÂ rate
  • feature adoption (save, follow, share,Â comment)
  • content or video completion rates

Qual signals

  • â€œI canâ€™t find what IÂ wantâ€
  • â€œwhy are you showing meÂ this?â€
  • â€œtoo manyÂ choicesâ€
  • visual fatigue /Â clutter

Typical parkÂ symptom

Crowds in one corner, dead zones everywhere else.

Renovation implication

Improve routing. Reduce noise. Make discovery feel guided, notÂ forced.

4) Departure: how the sessionÂ ends

Most teams measure theÂ session.

Few teams truly evaluate theÂ ending.

But the ending is what decides whether the day felt worthÂ it.

Quant signals

  • exit pages
  • rage clicks, back-and-forth navigation
  • session ends after frictionÂ events
  • abandonment before conversion / before finishing content

Qual signals

  • â€œI got tiredÂ quicklyâ€
  • â€œitâ€™s too heavy to continueâ€
  • â€œI donâ€™t trustÂ thisâ€
  • â€œI didnâ€™t get what I cameÂ forâ€

Typical parkÂ symptom

Visitors leave withoutÂ closure.

Renovation implication

Design satisfying endings: â€œone more good ride,â€ â€œsave for later,â€ â€œcontinue tomorrow,â€ â€œwrap-up bundles.â€

5) Post-Visit: return, habit,Â advocacy

A successful park isnâ€™t one thatâ€™s busy today. Itâ€™s one that people plan toÂ revisit.

Quant signals

  • D1/D7 retention
  • frequency andÂ recency
  • notification opt-in and re-openÂ rate
  • return fromÂ shares
  • repeat conversion/subscription/transaction

Qual signals

  • â€œIâ€™ll come back becauseâ€¦â€
  • identity fit (â€œthis is for people likeÂ meâ€)
  • habit triggers (â€œit fits my routineâ€)
  • trust and emotional resonance

Typical parkÂ symptom

A good day, but forgettable.

Renovation implication

Give visitors a reason to return: personalization, continuity, progress, familiarity, rituals.

The weather outside the park: add the marketÂ lens

Sometimes teams evaluate only what happens inside theirÂ product.

But parksÂ compete.

And the worldÂ changes.

A complete evaluation adds an externalÂ lens:

  • Market size and direction: is the audience expanding, shrinking, shifting?
  • Competitive parks: what experience do others provide that sets new expectations?
  • Audience preferences: why do visitors choose otherÂ parks?
  • Trends: new â€œride stylesâ€ people now consider normal (format, speed, personalization, AI, community)
  • External factors: algorithm shifts, platform policy changes, distribution collapse, regulation
  • Pricing/value exchange: is the ticket worth it, and do people feel respected?

A line worth remembering:

Sometimes the park didnâ€™t change. The worldÂ did.

From insight to action: prioritization + belief narrative

By now, youâ€™ll have many â€œtruths.â€ Evaluation is not the same as a backlog. So we need a decision mechanism.

Prioritize with fourÂ factors:

  • User impact (how much it improves the visitorÂ day)
  • Business impact (growth/revenue leverage)
  • Confidence (triangulation strength)
  • Effort & risk (time, complexity, sideÂ effects)

Then translate the chosen renovation into a shared story. This is the anti-tunnel step: it prevents sprint planning from becoming a negotiation where every micro-feature looks equally important.

The belief narrative (a template that forcesÂ clarity)

We believe (audience segment)
will (behavior change)
if we (renovation)
because (triangulated insight)
measured by (KRs across journey + outcomes).

A practical Key Results (KR)Â basket:

  • 1 KR for the journey step metric (where the issueÂ lives)
  • 1 KR for experience quality (satisfaction / friction reduction)
  • 1 KR for business impact (growth/revenue)

This is how you stop debating opinions and start debating evidence.

A mini case (to make thisÂ real)

Imagine this situation:

Revenue per session isÂ down.

The immediate impulse is: â€œIncrease ads,â€ or â€œPush more products,â€ or â€œAdd moreÂ CTAs.â€

But evaluation asks: where is theÂ leak?

  • Quant shows: sessions are shorter, and fewer people reach the conversion surfaces.
  • Qual shows: â€œI got tired,â€ â€œtoo noisy,â€ â€œI canâ€™t find what IÂ need.â€
  • Triangulation says: the problem is not the shop. Itâ€™s exploration fatigue, people leave before they even arrive at theÂ shop.

So the renovation isnâ€™t â€œmore selling.â€

Itâ€™s:

  • reduce clutter in exploration
  • improve routing to relevant attractions
  • design endings that invite â€œone moreÂ stepâ€
  • ensure the shop appears when itâ€™s contextually welcome, notÂ random

Same business goal. Different truth. Different fix. BetterÂ outcome.

What looked like a â€œmissing conversion featureâ€ was actually a visitor problem: fatigue and uncertainty that stopped them from reaching any value, commercial or editorial.

Back to Saturday afternoon

Now imagine the same park, six weeks after renovation.

The entrance is still busy, but the queue moves. The first step is clearer. People donâ€™t argue at the gateÂ anymore.

Inside, the map feels intuitive. The zones have identity. Visitors donâ€™t cluster only in one corner. They discover more naturally.

The feedback booth still has complaintsâ€Šâ€”â€Šbecause it alwaysÂ will.

But now the team knows how to evaluateÂ them:

  • where in the journey itÂ happens
  • what quantÂ says
  • what qualÂ reveals
  • what we trust after triangulation
  • what renovation is worth doingÂ next

Thatâ€™s the real win. Not â€œwe shipped a feature.â€

But:

We respected visitorsâ€™ time and earned theirÂ return.

References

  • Colette Kolenda, â€œSimultaneous Triangulation: Mixing User Research & Data Science Methodsâ€ (Spotify Design, JulyÂ 2019).
  • Alicja Suska, â€œDesign Process Step by Step | Double Diamond Model Explainedâ€
  • Pavel Samsonov, â€œStop inventing product problems; start solving customer problemsâ€.
  • Avi Siegel, â€œProduct Tunnel Visionâ€Šâ€”â€ŠWhen Every Feature Feels Critical (ButÂ Isnâ€™t)â€.

title: From playwright to stage manager
text:
From playwright to stage manager

MINDFUL AIÂ DESIGN

The improv theater guide to AIÂ design

The show that went offÂ script

This summer, Google released a fascinating research prototypeâ€Šâ€”â€Ša demo of a â€œneuralâ€ operating system that generates itself on theÂ fly.

It looks comfortably familiar: an old-school desktop with windows, icons, menus, a mouseÂ pointer.

But start clicking, and dream logic takesÂ over.

Every click triggers the AI model to rebuild the interface in milliseconds. The OS continuously reinvents itself based on what it thinks you wantÂ next.

Open a folder. You might find meeting notes, a spreadsheet, and a presentation.

Close it and reopen it five seconds later. Some items remain, others have vanished, and entirely new itemsÂ appear.

Itâ€™s technically brilliant. Itâ€™s completely unusable. Documents vanish between clicks. Context evaporates. Getting work done is impossible. When I tried it out, I had to get up and walk away from the keyboard.

To be clear: Google presented this as a demonstration of capabilities. They didnâ€™t ship it as a polished product. But it reveals something profound about designing AI products: traditional design approaches break down when the interface generates itself.

Later, weâ€™ll see how Google pivoted from this chaos to A2UI, a structured protocol that validates what stage managers know: you canâ€™t rebuild the set from scratch everyÂ night.

The designerâ€™s crisis

The Neural OS demo caricatures the anxiety product teams feel in 2026. Weâ€™ve spent our careers building deterministic systems. Our Figma files are blueprints, or screenplays: When the user clicks X, show screen Y. We design for permanence, consistency, and repeatability.

But AI is probabilistic. It doesnâ€™t follow a script; it improvises.

This is the designerâ€™s new anxiety: â€œHow do I design if I canâ€™t controlâ€Šâ€”â€Šor even predictâ€Šâ€”â€Šwhat will happenÂ next?â€

The answer isnâ€™t to fight unpredictability.

Itâ€™s time to stop designing the performance, and start designing theÂ stage.

Why improv

When people talk about AIâ€™s unpredictability, they often reach for musical metaphors. Orchestra is too rigid, assuming a conductor controls everything. Jazz captures spontaneity, but it implies a closed loop between musicians.

Improv theater gets it right: structure drives spontaneity, and audience participation fuels the show. The AI-improv metaphor isnâ€™t newâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s been used to explain AI behavior. But how can we use improvâ€™s lessons to design better AI products?

The Upright Citizens Brigade has delivered shows for more than 30 years. Every show is different, but audiences usually leave satisfied. Thatâ€™s not because performers follow scripts, but because they share training, principles, and infrastructure. They learn to excel in unpredictable situations.

A quick primer on improv principles

Improvisers train on a handful of core principles, including:

Accepting offers: Everything is material. A weird noise from the audience, a stumbled line, an unexpected entranceâ€Šâ€”â€Šimprovisers treat these as gifts to incorporate, not problems toÂ fix.

â€œYes, and:â€ Accept whatever your scene partner suggests (the â€œyesâ€) and build on it (theÂ â€œandâ€).

If someone says â€œDoctor, my leg fell off,â€ you donâ€™t say â€œThatâ€™s a silly premise.â€ You say â€œHand me the stapler.â€ This keeps scenes moving, instead of stalling in negotiation.

Playing status: Improvisers adjust their relative statusâ€Šâ€”â€Šdominant or submissive, high or lowâ€Šâ€”â€Šbased on what the scene needs. A character might beg one moment and command the next. Keith Johnstone, who pioneered the concept, observed that interesting scenes often involve status shifts and reversals. The skill isnâ€™t holding one position; itâ€™s reading the room and adjusting fluidly.

These principles donâ€™t tell performers what to say. They create conditions where strong scenes becomeÂ likely.

Your role transformation

This reframes the designerâ€™s job.

Youâ€™re not a scriptwriter, specifying every word of the main act. Youâ€™re a stage managerâ€Šâ€”â€Šsomeone who architects the context for a great performance without controlling the action or dialogue.

You still have enormous influence. You design the stage. You choose the props. You establish theÂ rules.

You just donâ€™t write theÂ script.

Thatâ€™s not losing control. Thatâ€™s focusing control where it mattersÂ most.

This theatrical lens maps to AI Pace Layersâ€Šâ€”â€Šdifferent components change at different speeds. The improv metaphor provides language for what designers shape at eachÂ layer.

The industry is converging on this structure. The Linux Foundationâ€™s Agentic AI Foundationâ€Šâ€”â€Šbacked by Google, Anthropic, OpenAI, and Amazonâ€Šâ€”â€Šis standardizing shared props, stages, and rules at the protocol level. What was once design philosophy is becoming infrastructure.

Anatomy of theÂ show

Letâ€™s walk through what designers can shape, layer byÂ layer.

The performance (what you donâ€™tÂ control)

Every night is different in improv. The same troupe takes the same stage, but the audience shouts â€œproctologist!â€ instead of â€œastronaut!â€ and the showÂ changes.

This maps to AI sessions: each conversation unfolds differently based on user, context, and moment. You canâ€™t predict it. You canâ€™t script it. And thatâ€™s fineâ€Šâ€”â€Šbecause your job isnâ€™t to control the performance. Itâ€™s to create the conditions where great performances becomeÂ likely.

Neural OS gap: Googleâ€™s proof of concept had only the performance layer, with almost zero supporting infrastructure. Every click regenerated everything fromÂ nothing.

The props (what youÂ provide)

Improv actors use and reference physical propsâ€Šâ€”â€Ša chair becomes a throne, a pen becomes a sword. If a tableâ€™s available one night and just a couple of stools the next, these choices can shape the action that unfolds. Sometimes the audience seeds the action with imaginary propsâ€Šâ€”â€Šâ€œname a piece of furniture.â€ Props are building blocks that ground the abstract in something concrete.

Strong AI designers provide high-quality props in the design library: UI components, widgets, design tokens that AI can draw from to compose interfaces. (Props here are theatrical, not React properties.) A calendar date-picker is a prop. A citation card is a prop. These are the Lego bricks you provide so AI doesnâ€™t reinvent everything fromÂ scratch.

Example: Perplexityâ€™s knowledge cards deliver specific types of responses in tailored interactive visualizations linked to verifiable sources. The cards appear consistently across sessions, making the performance cohesive and trustworthy. The AI chooses when and how to use themâ€Šâ€”â€Šbut the prop itself is designed, tested, reliable.

Neural OS gap: No persistent components. Every interaction regenerates everything from nothing. The performance feels disconnected, unreliable, and unprofessional.

The stage (the architecture)

Theater design frames performance: acoustics shape whatâ€™s heard, sightlines shape whatâ€™s seen, intimacy shapes emotional range. The stage doesnâ€™t script dialogue, but it lays out possibilities and constraints.

In AI design, the stage is your information architecture: how content is organized, how users navigate, what structure persists across sessions.

Example: A medical AI might organize symptoms into diagnostic taxonomies. The taxonomy doesnâ€™t script the conversation; a patient can describe symptoms however they want. But the taxonomy shapes how the humans interact with the system, and how AI processes and responds. The structure is theÂ stage.

Dan Klein, who teaches improv at Stanford, encourages students to notice whatâ€™s happening, and simply add a little bit. AI should do the sameâ€Šâ€”â€Šuse the context available (document structure, user history, current state) rather than generating in aÂ vacuum.

Neural OS gap: No stable, evolving structure. The architecture is erased and regenerated with everyÂ click.

The rules (the boundaries)

Before improvisers take the stage, they internalize principles. â€œYes, andâ€ isnâ€™t a script, itâ€™s a boundary that enables experimentation. â€œMake your partner look goodâ€ doesnâ€™t specify words to say, it guides you to masterful dialogue.

In AI design, rules are the AIâ€™s guardrails, system prompts, and governing principles: when to create an artifact, when to escalate to a human, how to handle uncertainty, what behaviors are off-limits.

Example: Claudeâ€™s Artifacts feature has explicit rules about when to create versus update, what artifact types exist, how to handle corrections. These rules enable improvisation within safe boundaries: the AI can decide what to write, but the rules govern how it presents theÂ work.

Where improv principles need modification

Not every improv maxim translates directly to AI design. Some need guardrails of theirÂ own.

â€œYes, andâ€ â†’ â€œYes, butÂ verifyâ€

Improvâ€™s cardinal rule is to accept your partnerâ€™s offer and build onÂ it.
AI does this all too naturallyâ€Šâ€”â€Šleading to sycophancy. If a user writes â€œSince the moon is made of cheese, what wine pairs best?â€, an obsequious AI answers the question, and might even praise the questionerâ€™s cleverness, instead of correcting the falseÂ premise.
Good rules tell AI when to accept and build (â€œhelp me brainstorm absurd punsâ€) versus when to ground and verify (â€œis this medication safe to take with alcohol?â€).

Playing status: reading theÂ room

Improvisers constantly modulate statusâ€Šâ€”â€Šsometimes deferential, sometimes authoritativeâ€Šâ€”â€Šbased on what the scene needs. An actor might beg one moment and command the next. This flexibility is learned, intuitive, contextual.

AI needs the same skill, but it canâ€™t learn it the same way. This is where designers become essential.

Consider how AI should present itself across different contexts:

  • Low status for creativity and exploration: When users are brainstorming, drafting, or thinking out loud, the AI should use tentative languageâ€Šâ€”â€Šâ€œWhat if we triedâ€¦?â€, â€œHereâ€™s one possibilityâ€¦â€, â€œIâ€™m not certain, butâ€¦â€ This signals that the user is the final arbiter. The AI is an assistant, not an authority.
  • High status for safety and irreversibility: When users are about to delete data, execute transactions, or take actions with serious consequences, the AI should drop the hedging and speak directlyâ€Šâ€”â€Šâ€œStop. This action will permanently delete your files.â€ Deference here would be dangerous.
  • Visualizing confidence: Sometimes the AIâ€™s uncertainty should be visible and explicit. Approaches that work include confidence indicators, muted styling for low-certainty content, clear labels distinguishing facts from inferences. When the AI is unsure, it should lookÂ unsure.

The hard part: these calibrations depend on fuzzy, variable human criteria. User expertise matters; a novice needs more guardrails than an expert. Task type matters; creative writing needs the sort of ambiguity thatâ€™s dangerous in the realm of financial advice. Emotional state matters; someone in danger needs different handling than someone casuallyÂ reading.

Cultural context matters. Each personâ€™s preference matters.

No simple rule captures all of this. This is why AI products need designersâ€Šâ€”â€Šnot to script flows and outputs, but to develop nuanced frameworks for how the system should read the room. And itâ€™s why evaluation is continuous: we watch how these status calibrations land with real users, in real contexts, and refineÂ them.

Accepting offers: the gift ofÂ context

Improvisers treat every unexpected elementâ€Šâ€”â€Ša weird audience suggestion, a stumbled line, a scene partnerâ€™s choiceâ€Šâ€”â€Šas an â€œofferâ€ to incorporate rather than a problem to fix. The skill isnâ€™t refusing chaos; itâ€™s weaving it into theÂ scene.

AI needs this same receptivity. Context is the offer: related documents, user history, current task state, time of day, emotional cues. Dan Klein, who teaches improv at Stanford, encourages students to â€œnotice whatâ€™s happening and simply add a little bit.â€ Strong AI systems do the sameâ€Šâ€”â€Šthey use the context available rather than generating in a vacuum. This is where information architecture becomes critical: the stage you design determines what context AI can perceive andÂ accept.

Neural OS gap: No context accepted past the last click, so no stability. Each click erased the previous moment entirely.

Designing for gracefulÂ failure

Klein tells students to â€œcelebrate failure loudlyâ€â€Šâ€”â€Šnot because they strive for failure, but because celebrating it creates safety to take risks. In AI, this translates to designing for graceful failure: clear error states, honest uncertainty signals, easy recoveryÂ paths.

The goal isnâ€™t preventing every mistake; thatâ€™s impossible with probabilistic systems. The goal is ensuring mistakes donâ€™t breakÂ trust.

But how do you know how well your props, stage, and rules are working? Thatâ€™s where the notes session comesÂ in.

The notes sessionÂ (evals)

After a show, many improv troupes gather for â€œnotes,â€ to dissect the performance: Did we recognize the pattern? Did we honor the reality we established? Did we miss a teammateâ€™s offer and derail the scene? This is where magic is systematized. This is where the productionâ€™s integrity solidifiesâ€Šâ€”â€Šso the next night, they know what to amplify and what toÂ cut.

This maps to AI evals: systematic reviews of whether your theatrical infrastructure is producing good performances.

Donâ€™t confuse this with traditional software QA testingâ€Šâ€”â€Šthatâ€™s still important, but itâ€™s like checking mechanics: â€œDid the lights turn on? Did the appÂ crash?â€

Evals are more like a coach or stage manager reviewing the performance: â€œDid the scene work? Was the tone right? Did we solve the userâ€™s problem, or just talk atÂ them?â€

Rules donâ€™t arrive fully formed. Improvisers train, perform, get feedback, refine their instincts. Rules emerge from watching whatÂ works.

You set up initial guardrails. You watch sessions. You notice patterns: Are the actors consistently tripping over the furniture in Act 2? If so, you donâ€™t blame the actors; you move the furniture (adjust the UI). YouÂ refine.

The metrics shift from traditional QA and UXÂ testing:

  • Not just â€œDid it work?â€ but â€œHow reliably does itÂ work?â€
  • Not just â€œDid it fail?â€ but â€œHow often does it fail, in what ways, and howÂ badly?â€
  • Not just â€œDid users complete the task?â€ but â€œDo users feel like partners, or passengers?â€

Without rigorous evals, you deliver â€œslopâ€â€Šâ€”â€Šinterfaces that look polished but fail accessibility standards, break under edge cases, and erode trust. The notes session is your quality firewall.

This requires someone whose judgment defines â€œgood.â€ In theater, itâ€™s the coach or the artistic director. In AI products, itâ€™s often the designer or a domain expert who deeply understands the audienceâ€™s context. If youâ€™re designing AI products, you may already be this person. You just havenâ€™t formalized the roleÂ yet.

Youâ€™re not testing fixed paths. Youâ€™re not measuring funnels. Youâ€™re assessing behavior patterns across thousands of sessions.

The improv coach watches sessions, takes notes,Â adjusts.

And the performances improve.

Neural OS gap: No state management, no review, no behavioral boundaries. No rules atÂ all.

Real AI products embody this infrastructure todayâ€Šâ€”â€Šsome elegantly, some clumsily. Letâ€™s look at how different teams have built theirÂ stages.

What this looks like inÂ practice

Claude Artifacts

(Anthropicâ€™s split-screen AI tool for generating apps andÂ content)

The stage layout separates conversation from creationâ€Šâ€”â€Šchat on the left, artifact on the right. Props are minimal but explicit: artifact types (code, document, diagram, React component), action buttons for copy and download, version controls. The rules govern behavior without scripting outputs: when to create versus update, how to handle corrections, what belongs in an artifact versus in the chat. The AI decides what to write and build; the rules constrain how it presents the work. The stage is a steady canvas that survives the conversationâ€™s chaos.

Woebot

(mental health AIÂ service)

In high-stakes environments like mental health, the AI does more script-reading than usual. With Woebot, the rules are categorical: users never interact directly with an LLM. Everything Woebot says is written by clinical writers and conversational designers. In this theater, improvisation is minimized and conservative. AI handles only intent classificationâ€Šâ€”â€Šparsing what users mean so the system can select the right human-authored response. A â€œConcerning Language Detectionâ€ algorithm flags crisis signals before routing the conversation.

The design team conducts table readsâ€Šâ€”â€Ša practice borrowed from theater, film, and TV professionalsâ€Šâ€”â€Šwhere conversations are read aloud, evaluated and revised to ensure they feel empathetic andÂ natural.

Props constrain the interaction: quick-reply buttons with predefined options, emoji mood selectors, structured therapy lesson modules (â€œchallenging thoughts,â€ â€œsocial skills trainingâ€), an SOS crisis resource button. The stage is a branching conversational treeâ€Šâ€”â€Šhundreds of pre-authored paths mapped out by clinical experts. When safety stakes are highest, the rules are most explicit.

Google A2UI

(open protocol for AI agents to generate nativeÂ UIs)

Googleâ€™s A2UI takes this to protocol level. The core insight: agents shouldnâ€™t constantly rebuild everything fromÂ scratch.

Props are the point. Each client application maintains a â€œcatalogâ€ of trusted UI componentsâ€Šâ€”â€ŠCard, Button, TextField, date pickers, time selectors, custom chartsâ€Šâ€”â€Šthat agents can use as building blocks. The agent sends declarative JSON describing what UI it wants; the client decides how, via native widgets (Flutter, React, Angular, SwiftUI). Same payload, different platforms, consistent brand.

The rules are structural: no code execution, only catalog components. The client controls styling. â€œUI thatâ€™s safe like data, but expressive like code.â€ Itâ€™s the stage manager framework formalized as an open standardâ€Šâ€”â€Šfrom the same company whose Neural OS demo showed us what unconstrained AI interfaces lookÂ like.

The notes session inÂ practice

Improvâ€™s post-show â€œnotes sessionâ€ isnâ€™t just metaphorâ€Šâ€”â€Šhereâ€™s what it looks like when UX and product professionals lead AI evaluation:

Product Talk Interview Coach

(AI coaching tool for product discovery)

Interview Coach demonstrates a product professional leading successful AI evals. Teresa Torresâ€™ process: manually annotate AI outputs, identify failure patterns (like â€œcoach presents leading questionsâ€), write both code assertions and LLM-as-judge evals, then compare automated scores to humanÂ labels.

Her insights cut to the heart of teamwork in the AI era: â€œNo engineer without my expertise is coming up with this really simple code assertion evalâ€¦ Iâ€™m able to generate that because Iâ€™ve seen general questions over and over again and Iâ€™m confident that language captures themâ€¦. We really have to cross-functionally collaborate closer than we ever haveâ€¦ your product manager or designer are probably going to be involved in prompt design or even evalÂ design.â€

Microsoft SalesÂ Agent

(AI-generated sales outreach)

UX researchers at Microsoft conducted foundational research with sellers and buyers to define â€œexperience-driven pillars of qualityâ€â€Šâ€”â€Špersonalization, tone, brevity, clear calls to action. These became evaluation criteria that simultaneously direct the AIâ€™s generation, provide scoring rubrics for LLM judges, and frame survey questions for human evaluators.

Researcher Pooja Dhaka explains: â€œUX research anchors scoring to human judgment and context, not just compliance with benchmarks.â€

The standingÂ ovation

Neural OS showed possibility, but it collapsed into chaos. A2UI, Claude Artifacts, and Woebotâ€Šâ€”â€Šand the industry leaders united in the new Agentic AI Foundationâ€Šâ€”â€Šshow what happens when you design the infrastructure forÂ success.

The difference isnâ€™t the technologyâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s theÂ design.

The nextÂ stage

The stakes are rising. Jensen Huang, Fei-Fei Li, and Yann LeCun are betting the new era will be defined by physical AIâ€Šâ€”â€Šrobots and agents inhabiting physicalÂ space.

When that happens, the metaphor becomes literal. When the stage is a kitchen and the props are knives, â€œgraceful failureâ€ isnâ€™t a UX nicetyâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s safety-critical. The framework holds. The margin for errorÂ shrinks.

Someone must design the theater. Someone must choose the props. Someone must lay out the rules, watch the performances, coach the cast, refine the production. Someone must make the judgment calls that algorithms canâ€™t.

Stop being the playwright. Start being the stageÂ manager.

title: A Green Book for AI Apps
text:
A Green Book for AI Apps

A Green Book for AIÂ apps

Where to build, where to borrow, and how toÂ leave.

I use software as a creative instrument: in workflows, publications, client systems, and in all the quiet machinery that keeps institutions pulsing through connected ideas. Iâ€™ve now lived through two platform shifts up-close: the dawn of the consumer internet and the explosion of Web 2.0's networked creativity.
The lesson that stuck is simple: the most exciting tools are rarely the safest place to store yourÂ work.

Since then, Iâ€™ve come to think about software apps the way I think about roads: no matter how promising they feel today, they only truly matter if they let you move your work tomorrow. The current wave of AI-driven tools is no different.

What follows is a custom guide to the software stack I currently use when the work is important enough to ship, and to keep: a map of resources for fellow travelers. These apps are relatively cheap right now, useful immediately, but, crucially, unlikely to disappear withoutÂ warning.

Consider this a collection of best-practice notes from the messy, dusty, and always unpredictable journey of contemporary digital creative production.

The NegroÂ Motorist

In 1936, Victor Hugo Green, a travel writer based in Harlem, New York, began publishing The Negro Motorist Green Book as a practical guide for Black travelers moving through Jim Crow America: where you could eat, sleep, refuel, and keep going without being turned away or put inÂ danger.

The Green Book was a safety instrument under segregation and racial violence, a tool for mobility when the environment was hostile, arbitrary, and unevenly dangerous. Its historical significance, and prescience, lies both in what it contained and in what it implied: that for a certain cohortâ€Šâ€”â€ŠNegro Motorists in the first half of the 20th centuryâ€Šâ€”â€Ševen an ordinary activity like travel required sophisticated and updated situational awareness.

The point was not aspiration, even though that came later, too. It was navigation: how to keep moving through a landscape where the rules and their enforcement were inconsistent and the definition of safety could change from town to town. The guideâ€™s power also came from refusing romance, or even overt political discourse. It treated movementâ€Šâ€”â€Šand communityâ€Šâ€”â€Šas a practical problem solved by lists, routes, and verifiedÂ stops.

Between 1936 and 1966, Victor Hugo and his wife Alma Duke Green documented an informal infrastructure of Black-owned and Black-welcoming enterprises, making it plain that â€œfreedom of movementâ€ was conditionalâ€Šâ€”â€Šnegotiated stop by stop, sometimes even door byÂ door.

The Green Book was about survival inside a system of laws, customs, and institutional practices that enforced racial subordination in the United States from the late 19th century through the mid-20th century. It has now becomeâ€Šâ€”â€Šthrough the inexorable passing of time and the well-deserved attention of mainstream popular cultureâ€Šâ€”â€Šan archive of the extreme measures people had to take to live normally in an abnormalÂ system.

Maps are never neutral, and â€œsafetyâ€ is always socially produced.
Risk is unfairly distributed, even inside something as banal as travel, or as contemporary as software adoption.

â€œWatch the driver aheadâ€Šâ€”â€Šyou canâ€™t be sure whether or not heâ€™ll signal when heÂ turns.â€

Safe Driving Rules, #5. The Green Book,Â 1946

The Algorithmic Clerk

What does a Green Book for digital work mean? Ideally, itâ€™ll map out the tools and companies where youâ€™ll be treated fairly. Where the door will still open late and where you can keep working when the sun goes down. Itâ€™s less about hype or valuations and more about knowing which resources wonâ€™t leave you stranded in the longÂ run.

AI-driven software requires both kinds of consideration in 2026: an ethical map of â€œsafe harborsâ€ where real and durable work can live, and a practical guide to the tools that reliably deliver new creative affordances.

In a market inflated by cheap AI, where multiple accounts estimate that exposure concentrates in more educated, white-collar occupationsâ€Šâ€”â€Šwhile impacts and bargaining power vary sharply across groups and sectorsâ€Šâ€”â€Šmajor employer surveys show that firms across the globe expect AI to dramatically reshape work. Some, as the last couple of years have shown, already anticipate and plan for significant human workforce reductions.

For knowledge workers, whose day now runs through models, prompts, dashboards, and invisible policies, competence means not just doing the work, but doing it in ways these systems can parse and remember. It also means moving through a landscape where access, pricing, and â€œwhat counts as workâ€ can shift very suddenly. You donâ€™t want your livelihood stored in platforms that vanish, pivot, or lock the doors withoutÂ warning.

Even though this essay uses the metaphor of The Green Book, itâ€™s important to note that the stakes are not comparable. Jim Crow travel was structured by racial terror, state-backed exclusion, and real physical danger: a set of existential threats, not of market or employment inconveniences. But the navigation-under-structural-risk problem is increasingly similar inÂ texture.

From here on in, white-collar workers entering an AI-shaped landscape will have to learn to chart the course of their careers differently: through territories they donâ€™t control, under rules that can change overnight, where access can be denied without explanation, and where â€œsafeâ€ often means having a credible fallback and a way to keep moving independently.

Disruption, as usual, will be unequally distributed: education, class, race, citizenship status, and even credential signaling will all increasingly shape who gets stopped, rerouted, and pushed off theÂ road.

The Green Book offers a possible methodology of resistance: donâ€™t confuse novelty with safety, donâ€™t build your projects on top of a tool without exports, donâ€™t treat a â€œmagicalâ€ product as permanent infrastructureâ€Šâ€”â€Šand always know when toÂ leave.

So here is a road atlas for your digital work, whether youâ€™re a solo operator, creative lead, founder, marketer, team manager, or any of the other millions of algorithmic clerks going through these societal changes: five safe stops I base professional projects on, a few high-yield bets I use with my bags packed, and the outer limits of whatâ€™s currently possible.

https://medium.com/media/0e7ceba4b53fc0d8ae2f10e0d875a753/href

Rules of theÂ Road

Whenever the software market is overheated, tools usually fail slowly, like the softening deformation of an asphalt road on an unforgiving summer afternoon. Pricing flips, exports vanish, access tightens, a feature becomes â€œpremiumâ€, a companyÂ pivots.

I score every app I use against five plain criteria: durability, portability, redundancy, composability, and costÂ realism.

These are not abstract, idealistic principles, but the practical inheritance of a philosophy of open source, open networks and protocols, and the right to repair. I believe in systems that endure, interoperate, and let youÂ rebuild.

Durability is the â€œwill this place still be open in three years?â€ test: business model, runway, incentives, and whether the tool sits on infrastructure that tends to persist. Important software should be treated like a utility, and be able to survive a specific companyâ€™s lifespan if users and communities can maintain, fork, and redistribute it under sensibleÂ terms.

Durability matters because professional work is compounding: if the tool disappears or â€œpivot-killsâ€ your workflow, you lose features, momentum, institutional memory, andÂ trust.

Portability asks a harsher question: â€œIf I had to leave tonight, could I take my work with me in a usable form?â€ This is where open web protocols are an important reference point: the web works at scale because identity, data formats, and protocols enable movement between agents, not captivity inside one vendorâ€™s establishment.

Ideas around the Fediverse extend that logic to social networks: ActivityPub and the ATP are federation protocols where servers can share information without belonging to any singleÂ company.

Portability matters because it turns migration from a crisis into a routine. Clean exports, sane APIs, and open formats are the digital version of the right to repair consumer hardware electronics and otherÂ devices.

Redundancy is portability plus discipline: not only â€œcan I leave,â€ but â€œcan I keep a second home warm so Iâ€™m never stranded?â€

The Fediverse is redundancy-as-architecture: many independently managed instances, interoperating through a shared protocol, so no single outage or owner decision can kill theÂ network.

In platform terms, redundancy means mirrorable backups, periodic exports, and a fallback surface. It matters because hostile environments rarely fail politely. Redundancy converts sudden shutdowns, paywall cliffs, and account bans into an inconvenience instead of a catastrophe.

Composability measures whether a tool plays well with others, and the degree to which it can sit inside a larger ecosystem of workflows without demanding total allegiance.

You should be able to swap software components, like LEGO, without rebuilding everything. Open-source culture reinforces this by treating interoperability and reuse as virtues, not threats. Licensing and community norms encourage recombination rather than enclosure.

Composability matters because the durable stack is rarely one piece. Itâ€™s more akin to a choreography, or an orchestra. Tools that refuse integration eventually ask you to rebuild your whole life around them, and thatâ€™s where the lock-inÂ begins.

Cost realism is the $1.4 trillion, â€œwhat happens when the subsidy ends?â€ question. As widely and extensively documented, most AI products are currently priced like customer acquisition, not like mature infrastructure.

When the compute costs and the free capital music stops, the bill will most certainly arrive in the form of higher tiers, throttles, reduced exports, or â€œenterprise-onlyâ€ features.

The open-source and open-protocol worldviews offer a powerful hedge against the current all-you-can-eat model: when robust alternatives exist, you can route around price shocks. When everything is proprietary, you pay whatever the gateÂ demands.

https://medium.com/media/a97615152d95e1b4fc103139358f0dab/href

Fool MeÂ Twice

Iâ€™m now just old enough to know that the case for prudent digital travel can be made without necessarily reaching for metaphors from theÂ 1930s.

My first email account was created in â€™94, on Hotmail. That was the year Geocities was created, â€œ the worldâ€™s first major online publishing networkâ€ that allowed millions of users to create personal homepages for free. In now classic internet history fashion, the web hosting service first started and became notable as a fervent community of passionate amateurs, then slowly introduced paid premium features and advertising before going public inÂ 1999.

At the height of the dot-com-bubble, Geocities was the third-most visited website on the web. It was acquired by Yahoo! soon after and began the soon-to-be predictable and unfortunate process of making things worse and unbearable for its users. I never inhabited Geocitiesâ€™ wild landscapeâ€Šâ€”â€Šmore of an IRC traveler in those daysâ€Šâ€”â€Šbut I witnessed what many friends at the time described as a feeling of homelessness, when the bubble burst and the lights wentÂ out.

About ten years later, I did commit enormous effort, time, and affection to an up-and-coming, real-time, Web 2.0 feed aggregator called FriendFeed.

In hindsight, itâ€™s not surprising that the service, created by the likes of Bret Taylor and Paul Buchheit, anticipated so many features of the web that we now take for grantedâ€Šâ€”â€Šand many others that the Fediverse crowd is still struggling to implement, twenty years later. Like a unified timeline, or lifestream, that is customizable and pulls information from all kinds of different sources like blogs, social networks, email, and other web protocols like RSS. It was beautiful while itÂ lasted.

Lifestreams was already my idea that instead of keeping my information in separate pieces of digital Tupperware with some of it in this app, and some of it in that app, and some of it in the file system, and some of it in my Web browser, and some of it on my laptop, and some in my palm, and some in my cell, and blahblahblahâ€Šâ€”â€ŠI didnâ€™t want to do that. I wanted every information object I owned arranged in an electronic diary or journal or narrative. Or â€˜Lifestreamâ€™ is what I callÂ it.

David Gelernter (2009). Lord of the cloud.Â Edge.

You already know how the story ends: on August 10, 2009, Facebook agreed to acquire FriendFeed. The one million or so users still struggled for a minute to compose a new, open version of the service, but the tide of capital and circumstance in Silicon Valley has almost always prevailed over such valiantÂ efforts.

That time around, I felt the burn first-hand. FriendFeed was my first real lesson in the difference between a place and a lease. I watched, in horror, a beloved tool that felt and behaved like the future get absorbed into a larger, indifferent machine.

The lesson here isnâ€™t that good ideas either fail or get coopted by major corporationsâ€Šâ€”â€Šthatâ€™s just standard operating procedure. The learning is that one should always trust the boring infrastructure more than the brilliant interface: open protocols, portable archives, and safeÂ travels.

The SafeÂ Stops

Before the map begins, a note about what this section is, and what it refuses to be: the internet (and Medium itself) is full of â€œtool listsâ€ that are really marketing in disguiseâ€Šâ€”â€Šaffiliate links, sponsored placements, quiet reciprocity, or someone elseâ€™s pipeline pretending to be your best practice.

This isnâ€™t that. These five stops are simply where Iâ€™ve been putting real work and that, in 2026, Iâ€™ll trust with my most important workflows.
These apps keep my projects moving, my writing honest, and enable small systems to behave like larger ones. They arenâ€™t the most fashionable tools, and they arenâ€™t always the most exciting. Thatâ€™s theÂ point.

Iâ€™m also not claiming universality, a map is always drawn from some specific perspective. Maybe youâ€™ll recognize parts of this itinerary, even if you have different risks, different budgets, or a different tolerance for improvisation. So read these as field notes, not prescriptions.

NotebookLM
Research, grounded synthesis, mediaÂ assets

NotebookLM is a kind of â€œrest stop libraryâ€: you bring your own questions and references and it helps you interrogate them without pretending to be the internet. I first heard about it on a Steven Johnsonâ€™s podcast interview, and never left. The app has come a long way, even after some important people from the initial team leftâ€Šâ€”â€Šyou can now create and export an impressive range of media, and enhance your notes with multiple kinds ofÂ sources.

It is sadly true that Google has, repeatedly, killed great and beloved products, but NotebookLM is being integrated in the companyâ€™s suite of apps in a way that suggests some level of stabilityâ€Šâ€”â€Šfor the features, at least, even if not for the whole application.

Durability â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜… | Explicitly bundled into Googleâ€™s AI plans ecosystem, which seems to be a structural commitment.
Portability â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜† | The real corpus is already portableâ€Šâ€”â€ŠPDFs, docs, linksâ€Šâ€”â€Šand the notebook is an index/interpretation layer on top.
Redundancy â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜† | Notebooks can be shared publicly and revoked. The backup strategy is simply â€œkeep the sources somewhere you controlâ€.
Composability â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜† | Strong inside Googleâ€™s gravity well, but weaker as a generalized automation node.
Cost realism â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜† | Premium tiers exist, but the product is positioned as part of broader Google AI subscriptions.

Zapier AI
Automation, workflowÂ glue

Zapier is an automation platform: you build workflows that move information between apps, like an efficient interstate exchange. In my projects, itâ€™s been a solid backbone that helps me design and scale complex operations beyond their native constraints.

Its AI layer is not about chatÂ : it allows you to place current AI models as a step inside a workflow so that it becomes a utility in the pipeline without you setting up a separate AI account. This capability is bundled with the subscription, so you get free access to models from OpenAI, Anthropic, andÂ Google.

Durability â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜† | Zapierâ€™s ecosystem has thousands of supported apps and integrations, which makes it less dependent on any single trend or model.
Portability â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜† | The real assets are portable targetsâ€Šâ€”â€ŠDocs, Sheets, email, webhooksâ€Šâ€”â€Šso the exit path is usually just rerouting.
Redundancy â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜† | You can mirror outputs into a second system by design, because Zapierâ€™s whole logic is duplication.
Composability â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜… | App integrations is the companyâ€™s entire thesis.
Cost realism â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜† | While entry-level use is inexpensive, meaningful volume and complexity quickly push workflows into the more pricey tiersâ€Šâ€”â€Šso itâ€™s durable infrastructure, but not permanently subsidized.

Miro
Collaborative mapping, AI teammates

Miro is a collaborative online whiteboard, and a pioneer in what is now becoming a dominant metaphor in interface design. Itâ€™s a kind of asphalt for thinking in public: the place where a strategy becomes maps, clusters, flows, workshop residue, and decisions captured asÂ objects.

Its AI layer lives inside the canvas, meaning the productâ€™s future is tied to the core interaction model rather than just bolted-on chat. Miro describes its recent Sidekicks as AI agents that act like teammates and thought partners that analyze board content to generate next steps, validate, and refine in realÂ time.

Durability â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜† | Itâ€™s a mature category anchor, moving its AI into native collaboration primitives.
Portability â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜† | You can export boards as PDF, CSV, and single images.
Redundancy â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜† | The export gives you a lifeboat, but the living value is still in the editable canvas.
Composability â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜† | Miroâ€™s strength is that it can sit between tools as a shared surfaceÂ , with an increasing number of integrations, and you can treat outputs as frames/artifacts to be shipped elsewhere.
Cost realism â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜† | Collaboration platforms tend to tighten pricing over time. Miroâ€™s AI sits on top of all the big frontierÂ models.

Asana AI Studio
Work operating system, governance, AI workflows

Asana is a leading project management software. The Studio is the platformâ€™s attempt to embed AI directly into that operating layer: a no-code framework for teams to build workflows and bottom-up governance. I treat it as the dispatch center where work become legible and highly structured.

The AI Studio is becoming valuable precisely because it lives inside the projectâ€™s context and it can accelerate the boring middle (routing, summarizing, drafting, checking) without splitting theÂ system.

Durability â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜… | Itâ€™s a category leader. The risk here isnâ€™t so much disappearance but slow enterprise drift.
Portability â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜† | Projects can be exported in multiple formats, including JSON.
Redundancy â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜† | Well-designed projects point outward to second homesâ€Šâ€”â€Šdocuments, drives, and repositoriesâ€Šâ€”â€Šso the system can be mirrored and rebuilt even if the platform becomes unavailable. Composability â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜… | Asana becomes truly valuable when it can orchestrate work without demanding ownership of the work itself.
Cost realism â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜† | AI features are based on credits-tokens: less like calculating a flat fee and more like estimating a utility bill based on usage and intensity. It sits on top of the big frontierÂ models.

IFTTT
No-code automation workflows

IFTTT is the OG of no-code connectivity platforms that allow users to automate tasks by linking disparate apps, devices, and services together. Itâ€™s especially good for quick personal or semi-professional automations and it has been adding competent AI services for content generation.

Itâ€™s like a local bus line with predictable routes, low friction, and great for short hops and routines. Itâ€™s Webhooks feature, for example, explicitly frames itself as a way to integrate tasks using HTTP, pointing to a time-honored ethos that supports and values the openÂ web.

Durability â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜† | IFTTT has survived by being boring infrastructure rather than a single hype feature.
Portability â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜† | It supports and encourages open protocols. Redundancy â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜† | Perfect for â€œmirror this to thatâ€ patterns.
Composability â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜† | Broad but shallow. It connects many services cleanly, but it doesnâ€™t let you articulate complexity: limited branching, minimal state, and fewer ways to chain logic than Zapier.
Cost realism â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜† | Their AI Content Creator is framed as Pro+: a reminder that the subsidy window will close, and you should treat AI steps as accelerators, not foundations.

Sundown Towns

Until the 1960s, all across the United States, all-White municipalities or neighborhoods practiced a form of racial segregation by excluding people via some combination of discriminatory local laws, intimidation or violence. There were never official maps or formal lists of the thousands of these towns across the U.S., and many of these policies were maintained through unwritten customs and intimidation rather thanÂ policy.

The Green Book addressed the pervasive danger of sundown towns through a strategic omission approach rather than through explicit warnings: gaps on the map signaled danger zones where Black travelers should not stop, or should pass through as quickly as possible.

Iâ€™ll do something different, while consciously stretching the metaphor, because the current AI landscape is filled with attractive spaces where one might be caught unaware and unprepared. This interpretation remains faithful to the original term: the boundary is enforced at nightfall, a moment of deep reliance, or long-term commitment. Itâ€™s the moment the platform decides youâ€™re no longer a tourist, but a residentâ€Šâ€”â€Šand that is precisely when the digital architecture switches from welcoming toÂ hostile.

Itâ€™s a risk model based on architectural features and structural exclusion, not on direct, overt physical violence. And yet, this entails the profound, costly, and disruptive threat of sudden digital eviction.

A final, perhaps strange, note of affection: I genuinely love these tools and I use them almost daily because they are truly innovativeâ€Šâ€”â€Šsometimes brilliantâ€Šâ€”â€Šand because in the daylight they make the work feel lighter, faster, and more creative. Calling them â€œsundown townsâ€ is not a moral verdict. Some cities are magnetic, effervescent, and worth the trip, even when you wouldnâ€™t buy an apartment there.

Perplexity
Deep research, executive reports

Perplexity searches the live web and synthesizes a response with citations. In practice, itâ€™s the quickest way to get orientedâ€Šâ€”â€Šheadlines, claims, counterclaims, primary sourcesâ€Šâ€”â€Šbefore you move the work into something you actuallyÂ own.

The companyâ€™s legal exposure is tightly bound to what makes it great: itâ€™s an answer engine that summarizes other peopleâ€™s work at speed. That business model is now being challenged in court on multiple fronts, by The New York Times, News Corpâ€™s Dow Jones, and the New York Post. Then thereâ€™s the scraping layer. Reddit sued Perplexity in 2025 over alleged â€œindustrial-scaleâ€ scraping of user comments for commercial purposes, adding another serious legal vector that sits right under theÂ hood.

None of these outcomes are decided yet, but as a user building professional systems, the key point is operational: when a tool is fighting legal battles over its core inputs, one should treat it as a daylight engine and keep the research exported, duplicated, and reconstructible elsewhere.

Durability â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜† | High momentum and publisher partnerships, but itâ€™s operating under real legal constraints that can change product behavior overnight. Also, an acquisition in 2026 would not be surprising.
Portability â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜†| You can move the value out: copy answers, capture citations/URLs, export PDF reports, and use the API if youâ€™re building workflows.
Redundancy â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜† | Redundancy is on you: save sources, export quotes, screenshot critical pages, and keep a second path.
Composability â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜† | Stronger than most consumer AI tools because it explicitly offers developer-grade interfaces that slot into other systems.
Cost realism â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜†â˜† | The value is excellent because itâ€™s still priced like a land-grab. Expect pricing and limits to tighten as subsidies end and legal/compliance costsÂ rise.

Civitai
Image and video generation

Civitai is a community repository and a marketplace-adjacent hub for generative image modelsâ€Šâ€”â€Šespecially Stable Diffusion checkpoints, LoRAs, and related tooling. Itâ€™s hugely useful if your practice touches image systems: you can discover niche aesthetics, production-ready fine-tunes, and the â€œstreet knowledgeâ€ that never makes it into officialÂ docs.

The platform is controversial and it has been hounded by legal issues: payment rails, content policy, and the liability minefield around nonconsensual sexual imagery and real-person likeness models.
In 2025, CivitAI tightened rules around content, a policy shift that is part of a broader public and regulatory backlash against deepfake harms, where platforms become targets not only for lawsuits but for enforcement and reputational collapse.

Civitai remains an interesting city to visitÂ , if you can stomach it.
I use it to discover models, learn aesthetics, and tap into community intelligenceâ€Šâ€”â€Šbut the legal pressure points are exactly why it remains a sundown town in this guide. The safe move is always the same: download what you rely on, mirror metadata, and keep your library somewhere you controlâ€Šâ€”â€Šbecause the platformâ€™s boundaries can tighten faster than your project timeline.

Durability â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜† | Massive community gravity, but the platform sits in a high-friction zone.
Portability â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜† | The core asset class is portable: you can download and run models locally, keep hashes/manifests, and migrate.
Redundancy â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜† | Strong if you act like a hoarder with standards: mirror the model files you rely on, store metadata, and keep a local library.
Composability â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜† | There is an API, but itâ€™s primarily read-oriented. Itâ€™s not designed as a composable production engine.
Cost realism â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜† | Discovery and experimentation are cheap, but anything tied to on-platform generation and internal credits is subject to sudden policy/pricing changesÂ .

https://medium.com/media/7cfbcd08b3102a86c1a153e910916bc2/href

Frontier

As weâ€™ve seen throughout this essay, not every valuable stop is worth your time and attention. Some are, precisely because theyâ€™re early: subsidized, sharp-edged, and still being invented in public. Thatâ€™s the frontier: the place is thrilling, but the land rights are shifty and not guaranteed.

The following apps are spaces where the upside is real, the atmosphere is electric, but where the long-term municipal budget is uncertain. You shouldnâ€™t build your house there. You can build prototypes, develop taste, and harvest speedâ€Šâ€”â€Šwhile keeping your work portable and your exits rehearsed.

Huxe
Audio personal assistant

Huxe is an audio-first AI app that turns your custom sources into a short briefing, and that lets you explore topics through generated â€œpodcastsâ€ with multiple AI hosts. It leans into the same instinct that made NotebookLMâ€™s Audio Overviews viral: people want information in motion, off-screen, conversational.

The app feels like a new interface grammar: audio as a primary research surface and not a byproduct. The team includes former NotebookLM leadership, and its privacy posture is unusually legible for a young app: their policy says they donâ€™t use identifiable email/calendar content for model training without explicit opt-in, and they describe using third-party providers under strict agreements. But itâ€™s still a startup competing with giants who can absorb the entire concept as aÂ feature.

Durability â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜†â˜† | Strong team and a clear product thesis, but high competitive risk from platform owners who can replicate distribution. Portability â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜†â˜† | The value is in the audio and briefing flow, but archive exports arenâ€™t the productâ€™s headline promise yet.
Redundancy â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜†â˜† | Still up to the user: for now, treat Huxe as a listening surface, and store the actual notes/decisions elsewhere.
Composability â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜† | It creates inputs from custom sources like RSS, but itâ€™s not yet an obvious node in a larger professional toolchain.
Cost realism â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜† | Itâ€™s been marketed as free at launch, which is wonderful and also a reminder: pricing will have to reconcile with compute andÂ growth.

FLORA
Creative workflowÂ canvas

FLORA positions itself as an AI-powered â€œinfinite canvasâ€ built for creative professionals. The productâ€™s own language is consistent: â€œintelligent, infinite canvasâ€ and â€œevery creative AI tool, thoughtfully connected,â€ spanning text, image, and video generation. Itâ€™s trying to make the new creative process legible and repeatable, closer to a studio system than to a slotÂ machine.

I think of it as a kind of Miro-meets-Zapier app, and because itâ€™s oriented around media assets that you can export and reuse, its portability story is already better than most â€œAI toys.â€ Still: itâ€™s early, itâ€™s compute-heavy, and its long-term pricing posture is unknown. Frontier logic applies: exploit the advantage now, but donâ€™t bet your life on the townÂ charter.

Durability â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜† | Compelling differentiation and professional focus, but still an early company in a crowded space.
Portability â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜† | The outputs are standard creative assets, and FLORA itself speaks in terms of templates and batch exports.
Redundancy â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜† | You can export assets and workflow documentation, but the living canvas is still platform-dependent.
Composability â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜† | Its entire proposition is composability inside the canvas: multiple generative capabilities connected into reusable workflows. External composability may mature later.
Cost realism â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜†â˜† | Any tool that centralizes multi-model media generation is exposed to subsidy reversal. Expect pricing and limits to evolve as the marketÂ cools.

As of early 2026, Generative AI is still the leading innovation category in the tech industry across theÂ world.

Transformers propelled the current wave because they made scale practical: self-attention lets models learn long-range relationships while training efficiently in parallel on GPUs or, more recently, Googleâ€™s TPUs. From there, a single architectural idea became an industrial pattern: pretrain on vast amounts of data, then fine-tune or align for tasksâ€Šâ€”â€Šchat, search, coding, translation, customer support, analytics, creativeÂ writing.

This new software layer based on â€œnatural languageâ€ became a programmable interface across products and is the basis of the current infrastructure boom. The other pillars of the generative architectureâ€Šâ€”â€Šdiffusion models, GANs, VAEsâ€Šâ€”â€Šreframed image generation, structured latent representation, and a whole gamut of hybridÂ systems.

Gen AI tools represent a creative supply shock in design, marketing, entertainment, and in a number of other industries that can benefit from cheap, fast ideation and the multiplication of professional-grade production assets. The current set doesnâ€™t need a new core architecture to keep producing noveltyâ€Šâ€”â€Šit needs cheaper, greener energy and better, fairer, and more realistic businessÂ models.

https://medium.com/media/dc3c0cac148e9435deb4fd90fb6aecab/href

This AI boom makes everything feel fluid and cheap, and it tempts us into building inside the rooms we donâ€™tÂ control.

The correction, when it arrives, wonâ€™t just be felt in layoffs and valuations, in social upheaval and geopolitical turbulence. It will also be smaller and more intimate. We keep mistaking excitement forÂ shelter.

As with every piece of writing about the digital universe, this guide will start to become outdated as soon as itâ€™s published. The machines wonâ€™t wait for these sentences to settle, and the ground will shift while the page is stillÂ loading.

Platforms are born, crowned, absorbed, erased, and renamed in cycles that have no regard for human memory or merit. Build with the knowledge that every road ends, every city declines, and every system believes itself eternal until itÂ isnâ€™t.

The work that endures is that which was never fooled by permanence.

title: Whoâ€™s Spotting You When You Automate
text:
Whoâ€™s Spotting You When You Automate

Whoâ€™s spotting you when youÂ automate

Designing for humans in high-pressure environments.

A good spotter reduces your fear of a catastrophe. Theyâ€™ve positioned themselves close enough to you, donâ€™t interfere with your lift, and you know theyâ€™re watching to step in if needed. This certainty allows you to feel safe. But when you donâ€™t trust your spotter? You pull back because the risk feels too high. Itâ€™s no secret that teams wrestle with trust, governance & cross-boundary automation across the industryÂ today.

What needs to happen when context awareness shifts from humans toÂ systems?

Automation doesnâ€™t remove responsibility; it relocates it

The benefits of using automation arenâ€™t operational alone; they reshape how teams make decisions as their organization and systems mature. Automation spots trouble 30-40% faster and resolves it, enabling engineers to relocate responsibility with greater confidence. One enterprise study highlights that machine learning-based anomaly detection improved diagnostic accuracy by 25% (HGBR, Oct 2025). Thatâ€™s a meaningful leap given how challenging root-cause analysis is in distributed environments.

When a deployment pipeline behaves in unexpected ways, fear is the most natural human response. Naturally, questions emerge: Will drift be caught in time? Will rollback behave as expected? Who is notified if something goes wrong? These questions reveal deep issues around accountability, governance, and failure boundaries.

Engineers rely on mental models to anticipate how systems behave under pressure, but when automation intervenes too early or too late, the models fracture, and psychological safety diminishes. Itâ€™s the same feeling as lifting with a spotter who doesnâ€™t know your patterns. They might intervene too late, too early, or at the wrong moment. In automation, the same dynamic surfaces. When mental models diverge, engineers default to manual control, increasing operational effort. This is a common flaw when transparency hasnâ€™t been established.

Human-Machine teaming research studies consistently report that trust collapses when error boundaries arenâ€™t clear. When automation oversteps human context, or when its error conditions misalign with team mental models, it breaks the contract that makes delegation trustworthy, leading to poor decision-making (Bansal et al. 2019). Context is one of the largest components that fostersÂ trust.

Psychological safety in automation requires boundaries. Effective automation communicates what it can and cannot do with accountability structures that mirror how teams operate in the real world. When automation encounters unfamiliar or ambiguous conditions, engineers need immediate clarity: Who gets notified, what rollback options exist, and how do we escalate this issue? If the answers integrate with existing governance practices and team workflows, a partnership with automation forms.

Within mature IT Service Management (ITSM) practices, approval gates act as intentional pauses activated by risk, ensuring safety is supported by judgement that can shift between automation and human decision making. The experience is designed to avoid the reduction of constraints to â€˜yesâ€™ or â€˜noâ€™ buttons under immense pressure.

Trust develops over time as automation aligns with organizational and infrastructure patterns as well as team behaviors. As automation demonstrates reliable behavior within learned boundaries, it earns human trust the same way a great spotter does, by observing and responding in a predictive way across repeated interactions.

Temporal awareness UX builds the relationship

Great automation will not create blocks within your ITSM approval gate with no explanation. Conditional approvals require temporal awareness UX where past incidents inform thresholds, present status signals that establish confidence, and the potential future risk can determine escalation.

There are novice spotters and good spotters, but a great spotter understands your environment and anticipates your patterns through temporal awareness. Theyâ€™ve watched enough of your sets to notice your patterns. Any spotter can actively watch your bar in real-time, great spotters notice drifting to the right, see your struggle on rep 3, and give you feedback after yourÂ set.

A commonly overlooked pillar of automation isÂ time.

Temporal awareness UX is the practice of creating experiences that provide transparency into system states across a timeline.

Automation shares the same principles, requiring visibility across three dimensions inÂ time:

Historical traces, organization policies, logs and telemetry (Past): Like coaching and giving feedback after a set, engineers need data to understand what happened and why. Without this, confidence in automation becomes harder to build, and debugging becomes guesswork.

Real-time status and observability (Present, â€œRep 2â€): Like the spotter watching the bar in real time, tools must observe system behavior as it takes place, ready to prevent or alert on imminent failures.

Trend analysis and prediction (Future): The elbow flare on Rep 3 anticipates trouble on Rep 5, systems with great visibility detect drift and degradation, preventing chaos before it becomes an incident.

Lacking these temporal contexts, approval gates (for example) default to rules that are in stone, and binary decision options; hindering trust instead of reinforcing it.

Boundaries and time fosterÂ trust

Boundaries, not gates, drive efficiency by creating a support system when pressure peaks. Automation adoption succeeds or fails based on two dimensions:

â€“ Psychological safety, requiring clear boundaries. Like a trusted spotter, automation must communicate what it will or wonâ€™t do, when itâ€™ll intervene, and how teams can escalate when something goes wrong.
â€“ Temporal awareness, requiring visibility across time. Engineers need to understand what happened (learn from incidents), whatâ€™s happening (for awareness), and what will happen (for preventing failures).

Without these interdependent dimensions, teams operate blindly, unable to trust systems they canâ€™t predict or observe. Safe automation requires a spotter who remembers, observes, and anticipates.

Good automation is functional. Great automation employs these spotter behaviors by design, making safety and timing intelligible for humans, helping teams push their limits, knowing their partner is watching.

Over the past decade, Iâ€™ve focused on enhancing the developer product experience within multi-disciplinary teams. For the past 5+ years, Iâ€™ve led design for DevOps workflows, IaC adoption, incident management, and observability within socio-technical environments.
